content.webTitle: Going out to bat for cricket diplomacy | Brief letters

fields.headline: Going out to bat for cricket diplomacy
fields.bodyText: We were thrilled to see that Welsh is now “cool” (G2, 13 June). After 40 years of going to the Brecon Beacons national park every holiday and any spare time we have, we decided it was time to learn the language. We started in January (the oldest people in the class by far), and are finding it extremely difficult, but are determined to keep going – whether cool or not. Dyn ni’n siarad Cymraeg, afall! Joanie Speers Llanddeusant, Carmarthenshire (and London) • Cricket diplomacy – what a good idea (Rain fails to stop play as new friends turn out for old rivalry, 17 June). With a great former cricketer as prime minister of Pakistan, this surely should be pursued. It was a tragedy when Nehru and Jinnah, who had led the campaign for independence together with Gandhi, forced partition, with the loss of a million lives at the time and continuing conflict, actual or potential, ever since. How about a Test match between a joint India/Pakistan team and the Rest of the World? Frank Jackson Harlow, Essex • I’m a fan of bluegrass music (Plucked from obscurity, Review, June 15), which is often played by virtuosos, but the assertion that it is “as improvisatory as jazz” is a preposterous suggestion, as untrue as it is unnecessary. David Flower London • Considerable anger has been expressed at the withdrawal of free TV licences for the over-75s (Report, 11 June). Could Sky show the way by offering its services free for this age group? Peter Curbishley Great Durnford, Salisbury • Doreen Weppler-Grogan (Letters, 17 June) refers to the island of Cuba as “tiny”, but Cuba is the largest island in the Caribbean, half as big as the UK and almost as large as England. Richard Rios Miami, Florida, USA
